ORG 3 Most people are aware that their blood pressure and cholesterol numbers are important in knowing their risk for heart and blood vessel diseases. Yet few know about estimated glomerular filtration rate (estimated glomerular filtration rate), one of the numbers that measures the health of their kidneys. This brochure explains what estimated glomerular filtration rate is, how it is measured, and why it is important in understanding chronic kidney disease (chronic kidney disease). How do doctors check for kidney disease? Kidney disease can be found with two simple tests: A urine test for protein (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio) A blood test for creatinine (estimated glomerular filtration rate) Even if these tests are normal now, they should be repeated in the future, especially if you are at increased risk for kidney disease. Wouldnt I know if something was wrong with my kidneys? Not always. Early kidney disease can be silent, without pain or other symptoms. Most people do not know that they have early kidney disease. When kidney disease gets worse, some people do notice problems such as swelling around the ankles, puffiness around the eyes, high blood pressure, nausea, poor appetite, or vomiting. 4 NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION What is estimated glomerular filtration rate (estimated glomerular filtration rate)? Your estimated glomerular filtration rate tells a lot about how well your kidneys are working. Your kidneys are important. They keep you healthy. They filter out waste and extra fluid from your blood, help make red blood cells, and keep your bones strong. When kidneys arent working well, wastes build up in your blood. Your bones can become weak. You may not have enough red blood cells for your bodys needs. Your estimated glomerular filtration rate number is a calculated measurement of how well your kidneys are working. If your estimated glomerular filtration rate number is low, your kidneys may not be working as well as they should. Its important to find this out early. Early treatment may help keep kidney disease from getting worse. How is estimated glomerular filtration rate checked? Having a simple blood test for creatinine is the first step in checking your estimated glomerular filtration rate. Creatinine is a waste product made by your bodys muscles. Your kidneys usually keep the level of creatinine just right. The level of creatinine in your blood, your age, and gender are used to calculate your estimated glomerular filtration rate. Do you know what your estimated glomerular filtration rate is? Your healthcare professional or testing lab usually calculates your estimated glomerular filtration rate number. Be sure to talk with your doctor about the result. KIDNEY.

Your healthcare provider will tell you the stage of kidney disease, based on how well your kidneys are working and your estimated glomerular filtration rate (estimated glomerular filtration rate). The estimated glomerular filtration rate number comes from a lab test that measures the amount of blood your kidneys are filtering each minute. As chronic kidney disease gets worse, the estimated glomerular filtration rate number goes down. Yes. estimated glomerular filtration rate gets lower with age, even in people without kidney disease. The older you are, the lower your estimated glomerular filtration rate. For this reason, the estimated glomerular filtration rate calculation takes age in to account. At any age, an estimated glomerular filtration rate below 60 for three months or more indicates kidney disease. estimated glomerular filtration rate Declines with Age (even in people without kidney disease) Age (years) Average estimated glomerular filtration rate 2029 116 3039 107 4049 99 5059 93 6069 85 70 75 8 NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION If my estimated glomerular filtration rate is low, what are the next steps? More tests should be done to understand why it is low. The results of these tests may provide clues about what is happening with your kidneys. Examples of tests that might be ordered are: Urine tests that look for: The type and amount of protein in your urine (a sign of kidney damage) Red blood cells (a sign of bleeding in the urinary system) White blood cells (a sign of infection) Ultrasound or computed tomography scan to get a picture of your kidneys and urinary system. These pictures show the size of your kidneys and if tumors, kidney stones, or cysts are present. A biopsy to remove a tiny piece of the kidney for evaluation. The sample is studied under a microscope to see what kind of kidney damage is may be present. KIDNEY. ORG 9 Am I at increased risk for kidney disease? Some people are more likely than others to develop kidney disease. You may be at increased risk for kidney disease if you: Have diabetes Have high blood pressure Have a family history of kidney disease or kidney failure Are age 60 or older Are overweight or obese If the tests find kidney disease, what does it mean for my health? If you have kidney disease, your kidneys have lost some of their ability to keep you healthy. They arent able to do their full jobs: filter your blood, help make red blood cells, and keep bones strong. The most common causes of kidney disease are diabetes and high blood pressure. There are also other problems caused by kidney disease like high blood pressure, poor nutrition, and heart disease. 10 NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION Can treatment keep kidney disease from getting worse? The earlier your kidney disease is found, the better. If it is found and treated early, you may be able to keep it from getting worse. That is why it is so important for people with risk factors to be tested for kidney disease. Heart and blood vessel problems Poor nutritional health High blood pressure Anemia Bone problems Kidney disease affects many areas of the body. KIDNEY. ORG 11 The success of treatment depends on a number of things: Your stage of kidney disease when you start treatment. The earlier you start, the better you are likely to do. How carefully you follow your treatment plan. Learn all you can about kidney disease and its treatment. Talk to your doctor about what you can do. What caused your kidney disease. Some kidney diseases are more difficult to control. 12 NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION Key Points to Remember: Two simple tests will find chronic kidney disease: A urine test for protein (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio) A blood test for creatinine (estimated glomerular filtration rate) Get a blood pressure measurement.

estimated glomerular filtration rate is an important number that estimates how much kidney function you have. If you have kidney disease, a treatment plan will be developed especially for you. It will be based on your estimated glomerular filtration rate, the cause of your kidney disease, and other health factors. Your doctor will monitor your stage of kidney disease using your estimated glomerular filtration rate. You should keep track of it, too. You can keep kidney disease from getting worse by following your treatment plan carefully. If kidney disease progresses to kidney failure, dialysis or a kidney transplant will be needed. KIDNEY. A trained professional will listen to your concerns and answer your questions. 14 NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION Setting a standard for care The National Kidney Foundation, through its Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative (Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative), defines stages of kidney disease and offers guidelines that help your healthcare professional and healthcare team make important decisions about your medical treatment. The information in this booklet is based on those recommended guidelines. The information contained in this publication is based on current data and expert guidance available at the time of publication. The information is intended to help patients become aware of their disease and its management. This publication is not intended to set out a preferred standard of care and should not be construed as one. Neither should the information be interpreted as prescribing an exclusive course of management. Patients should always consult with their healthcare providers regarding decisions about their individual plan of care. KIDNEY.
